4ADA2F33EA4F4398929DD8EC4A157C68.description: Science assumes consistent patterns in natural systems. (4- ESS1-1)

91999D7171914694BD0FF1711E1E878F.description: Scientific Knowledge Assumes an Order and Consistency in Natural Systems

7570BADE67214736A77530032E548435.description: Engineers improve existing technologies or develop new ones to increase their benefits, to decrease known risks, and to meet societal demands. (4-ESS3- 2)

0340680E76CF40BA90E27E6476677AA2.description: Influence of Science, Engineering, and Technology on Society and the Natural World

10076686A086445487C6F806B2B188CF.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified, tested, and used to explain change. (4- ESS2-1),(4-ESS3-2)

F92AE283D29249749965B7EE28B7F780.description: Patterns can be used as evidence to support an explanation. (4-ESS1-1),(4- ESS2-2)

82338FA98BEE475F9EBE0C7C626694D4.description: Testing a solution involves investigating how well it performs under a range of likely conditions. (secondary to 4-ESS3-2)

42947DCE38084E1FB47FCE4CFA3A4894.description: ETS1.B: Designing Solutions to Engineering Problems

ECC4ECD0BB4B4D278EBA05C17E8B838C.description: A variety of hazards result from natural processes (e.g., earthquakes, tsunamis, volcanic eruptions). Humans cannot eliminate the hazards but can take steps to reduce their impacts. (4-ESS3-2) (Note: This DisciplinaryCore Ideacanalsobefoundin 3.WC.)

808E059DC0454347BD733C0082DDBD43.description: Living things affect the physical characteristics of their regions. (4-ESS2-1)

2F928C70EFAD4EDB96462ECD6111CAD8.description: The locations of mountain ranges, deep ocean trenches, ocean floor structures, earthquakes, and volcanoes occur in patterns. Most earthquakes and volcanoes occur in bands that are often along the boundaries between continents and oceans. Major mountain chains form inside continents or near their edges. Maps can help locate the different land and water features areas of Earth. (4-ESS2-2)

BC39AE42C19E45BCA7534F089BA92452.description: ESS2.B: Plate Tectonics and Large-Scale System Interactions

34C2279D573F41EEAA21FBA02022E0E9.description: Rainfall helps to shape the land and affects the types of living things found in a region. Water, ice, wind, living organisms, and gravity break rocks, soils, and sediments into smaller particles and move them around. (4-ESS2-1)

31C7799763EB44E18AF1CFF6C8AD49A4.description: Local, regional, and global patterns of rock formations reveal changes over time due to earth forces, such as earthquakes. The presence and location of certain fossil types indicate the order in which rock layers were formed. (4-ESS1-1)

5F6B989A2C3C4791AAEF9C004F81125C.description: ESS1.C: The History of Planet Earth

3A3825B6AAFB4449A94407DABDB1255F.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem based on how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the design solution. (4-ESS3-2)

331C6C563B864E84BBBB267FAECC14BD.description: Identify the evidence that supports particular points in an explanation. (4-ESS1-1)

88A434DFC36641E6BD14A312CE0078B2.description: Make observations and/or measurements to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence for an explanation of a phenomenon. (4-ESS2-1)

AB5745CF57C442B0B47EA6449194EACF.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to reduce the impacts of natural Earth processes on humans.

035E77A655A2411A88BBF1B66A6D6603.description: Analyze and interpret data from maps to describe patterns of Earth’s features.

1F54B39F14624226A60CA0067DBC9D54.description: Make observations and/or measurements to provide evidence of the effects of weathering or the rate of erosion by water, ice, wind, or vegetation. [

14405B66D4B9469FB4D0352567657693.description: Identify evidence from patterns in rock formations and fossils in rock layers to support an explanation for changes in a landscape over time.

6216169113B04AD38E19B05AF245BB6B.description: 4. Earth's Systems: Processes that Shape the Earth

8993CBD4D1EF422599F0020BDF1261A0.description: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions. (4- LS1-1), (LS1-2)

3830F310EC074848881A1F62FA0B011D.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified. (4-PS4 2)

6EDCAEFF53A944D79B4DA61D8E9C245A.description: Different sense receptors are specialized for particular kinds of information, which may be then processed by the animal’s brain. Animals are able to use their perceptions and memories to guide their actions. (4-LS1-2)

7E4FAF693B0A48E28B05A36AEE4067D0.description: Plants and animals have both internal and external structures that serve various functions in growth, survival, behavior, and reproduction. (4-LS1-1)

108DCA3AAD2E43889AF65A37B511BE13.description: An object can be seen when light reflected from its surface enters the eyes. (4-PS4-2)

FAA12AB623AB4499A01286A27FC351A0.description: Construct an argument with evidence, data, and/or a model. (4-LS1-1)

437C90F0D4334162A11455EEE8C01B75.description: Use a model to test interactions concerning the functioning of a natural system. (4-LS1-2)

A005052272774E7083151BFE4D6FE935.description: Develop a model to describe phenomena. (4- PS4-2)

ECEDF877F3D94F1EA6509C6037C68C2E.description: Use a model to describe that animals receive different types of information through their senses, process the information in their brain, and respond to the information in different ways.

C243780FC9554456A971DC8739D78C05.description: Construct an argument that plants and animals have internal and external structures that function to support survival, growth, behavior, and reproduction.

740DD66F00BC4238A7C7883B1E7B14F1.description: Develop a model to describe that light reflecting from objects and entering the eye allows objects to be seen.

DE0E8611B9E24B3D8156F148CCF57C1A.description: Knowledge of relevant scientific concepts and research findings is important in engineering. (4-PS4-3)

8C9F214ABDD94CD5BD831CD976154CAC.description: Similarities and differences in patterns can used to sort and classify designed products. (4-PS4-3

48DDEF2739CB4303AF36FEB3026B1D8D.description: Similarities and differences in patterns can used to sort and classify natural (4-PS4-1)

E331A9D7810141E19CFE402512668BA2.description: Different solutions need to be tested in order to determine which of them best solves the problem, given the criteria and the constraints. (secondary to 4-PS4-3)

540476103FED45E689B7D0F152A7B287.description: Digitized information can be transmitted over long distances without significant degradation. High-tech devices, such as computers or cell phones, can receive and decode information—convert it from digitized form to voice— and vice versa. (4-PS4-3)

3B96E7CD02D3448CA9309E7B2D0E8407.description: Waves of the same type can differ in amplitude (height of the wave) and wavelength (spacing between wave peaks). (4-PS4-1)

0188AC334A7A40C491B4D546CBFFA51B.description: Waves, which are regular patterns of motion, can be made in water by disturbing the surface. When waves move across the surface of deep water, the water goes up and down in place; there is no net motion in the direction of the wave except when the water meets a beach. (Note: This gradebandendpoint was moved from K–2).(4-PS4-1)

49500E71F26344B0971248338C9CCA5C.description: Science findings are based on recognizing patterns. (4-PS4-1)

0D11C3F83E104027B402505C90E6AE65.description: Develop a model using an analogy, example, or abstract representation to describe a scientific principle. (4-PS4-1)

895C35A19F39486296729ECF47BA0A69.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions that use patterns to transfer information.

7EC5E274DFCB4AAE9F5D4DED25FCDCF3.description: Develop a model of waves to describe patterns in terms of amplitude and wavelength and that waves can cause objects to move

B8CD9B7D12B040E6A0129A4E07B6C6AD.description: Most scientists and engineers work in teams. (4-PS3-4)

06A6CEB89C5B4ECA9C6CB3EF847CFAE2.description: Over time, people’s needs and wants change, as do their demands for new and improved technologies. (4-ESS3- 1)

8895017773FD4D4DB59811F65CACB7F4.description: Influence of Engineering, Technology, and Science on Society and the Natural World

9A263E72EBE14176AFC75490B8C61399.description: Knowledge of relevant scientific concepts and research findings is important in engineering. (4-ESS3- 1)

D8595DBE02624DD0AD0C3464DE992879.description: Interdependence of Science, Engineering, and Technology

DB88A1DA2D1E4F74A1E2A589CA3BFD98.description: Energy can be transferred in various ways and between objects. (4-PS3-1),(4- PS3-2),(4- PS3-3),(4-PS3-4)

A656540FD28E4F799DBB790752181B65.description: Cause and effect relationships are routinely identified and used to explain change. (4-ESS3-1)

5B0949A6229348E7853C81FA0AECA990.description: Possible solutions to a problem are limited by available materials and resources (constraints). The success of a designed solution is determined by considering the desired features of a solution (criteria). Different proposals for solutions can be compared on the basis of how well each one meets the specified criteria for success or how well each takes the constraints into account. (secondary to 4-PS3-4)

7399243ABA68438AB80B33E8AE067365.description: Energy and fuels that humans use are derived from natural sources, and their use affects the environment in multiple ways. Some resources are renewable over time, and others are not. (4-ESS3-1)

376775ECA4D74CE9AF95BE790A85C432.description: The expression “produce energy” typically refers to the conversion of stored energy into a desired form for practical use. (4-PS3-4)

2F48EE2306F444EFBDE42021837F67BE.description: PS3.D: Energy in Chemical Processes and Everyday Life

1ABDABF7828247D4A8B1672355B74B60.description: When objects collide, the contact forces transfer energy so as to change the objects’ motions.(4-PS3-3)

0A068C0185414F65882D201FF78B9CEA.description: PS3.C: Relationship Between Energy and Forces

214C82DDAC4F4883AA2B34E0F33EE9BB.description: (NYSED) Energy can also be transferred by electric currents, which can then be used locally to produce motion, sound, heat, or light. The currents may have been produced to begin with by transforming the energy of motion into electrical energy. (4-PS3-2),(4-PS3-4)

67BD9E0140844CBD9256E24C9835483C.description: Energy is present whenever there are moving objects, sound, light, or heat. When objects collide, energy can be transferred from one object to another, thereby changing their motion. In such collisions, some energy is typically also transferred to the surrounding air; as a result, the air gets heated and sound is produced. (4-PS3-2),(4-PS3-3)

C5173283B6A94F3C85918EEA339B3423.description: PS3.B: Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

8CF8527C59644561A1DC7B9E64ADA682.description: (NYSED) Energy can be transferred by moving objects or by sound, light, heat, or electric currents. (4-PS3-2), (4-PS3-3)

B6A6EAE1663B43888C32C0C1DC4CA4D4.description: (NYSED) A given object possesses more energy of motion when it is moving faster. (4-PS3-1)

995B5B79F75D42519932527FEDAF3F2F.description: Obtain and combine information from books and other reliable media to explain phenomena. (4- ESS3-1)

6247498978ED40E8904167B600D36BE3.description: Apply scientific ideas to solve design problems. (4-PS3-4)

59A3CAA129B84848B2466E3DA8601820.description: Use evidence (e.g., measurements, observations, patterns) to construct an explanation. (4-PS3-1)

33D4B5E85657491BA6B088603D85F01A.description: Make observations to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence for an explanation of a phenomenon or test a design solution. (4-PS3-2)

F56381CDC8254337AC5AA17052E99487.description: Ask questions that can be investigated and predict reasonable outcomes based on patterns such as cause and effect relationships. (4-PS3-3)

71EE13F487B842ACA9092C68D8F0D701.description: Obtain and combine information to describe that energy and fuels are derived from natural resources and their uses affect the environment.

32D5AA100EBC45B99FB9419867B5288E.description: Apply scientific ideas to design, test, and refine a device that converts energy from one form to another.

351145C30077417D9F687D0A5FA384EE.description: Ask questions and predict outcomes about the changes in energy that occur when objects collide

6CE89F74C1E24A64B7BF4E48BF75393E.description: Make observations to provide evidence that energy is conserved as it is transferred and/or converted from one form to another.

8465CD2DA57C42D28E2FB7293BFA27E2.description: Use evidence to construct an explanation relating the speed of an object to the energy of that object.

2BEE4B82D8A04410B447D090DA0DBA63.description: Engineers improve existing technologies or develop new ones to increase their benefits, decrease known risks, and meet societal demands. (3-5-ETS1-2)

68C8339182CC40D7A0A36334C42E8144.description: People’s needs and wants change over time, as do their demands for new and improved technologies. (3-5-ETS1-1)

F68DCA42231642D1836A8A5ADF317232.description: Influence of Science, Engineering, and Technology on Society and the Natural World

C0C232D2AAC7451080ACFDC164FF4F1A.description: Different solutions need to be tested in order to determine which of them best solves the problem, given the criteria and the constraints. (3-5-ETS1-3)

DD20FAED29D448AFBC9E21B86A25C1F5.description: Tests are often designed to identify failure points or difficulties, which suggest the elements of the design that need to be improved. (3-5-ETS1-3)

46894A332C674152A0725143D17CC1B0.description: At whatever stage, communicating with peers about proposed solutions is an important part of the design process, and shared ideas can lead to improved designs. (3-5-ETS1-2)

AD28DF77696641D693E5B9F2403E89F4.description: Research on a problem should be carried out before beginning to design a solution. Testing a solution involves investigating how well it performs under a range of likely conditions. (3-5-ETS1-2)

98B7FA5D6C6B4A039CE6DDDF26B248A8.description: Possible solutions to a problem are limited by available materials and resources (constraints). The success of a designed solution is determined by considering the desired features of a solution (criteria). Different proposals for solutions can be compared on the basis of how well each one meets the specified criteria for success or how well each takes the constraints into account. (3-5-ETS1-1)

5AFE3B6E72084534B2C80BA0A5644339.description: ETS1.A: Defining and Delimiting Engineering Problems

A1FD1EBB36FB4AA8A083BB9E8CD1E01C.description: Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem based on how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the design problem. (3-5-ETS1- 2)

9A51031B85FF40D18FBE8E560B8AA934.description: Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence, using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered. (3-5-ETS1-3)

8B7D6A960DD540C3B8B93B867AEA558D.description: Define a simple design problem that can be solved through the development of an object, tool, process, or system and includes several criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost. (3-5- ETS1-1)

2023DAF8D83B43289F6E7B54494E2370.description: Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

2296AAC196F4416C8E9538BAC9B648F3.description: Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

9CF12139F3DF41148FEA1A5AB75AC67E.description: Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.

7A7D4D7288D04D868A1AA855E74109A4.description: NY State State Grade 4 Science Standards
